 In 350, Pope Julius I declared that Christ's birth would be celebrated on December 25. A theory is just a model that accurately and repeatedly describes our observations of a physical system. Asking whether they are "true" or "false" is meaningless, either the theory can be shown to be accurate by experimentation or it can't.
 
 Long-standing scientific theories can pretty much be assumed to be "true", but not in a literal sense because as time goes on new theories may be proposed which describe these phenomena more accurately.
 The perfect example is Einstein's General Relativity, which among many other things described the orbits of the planets to a greater degree of accuracy than Newton's laws of motion. However Newton's laws can still be used on a small scale as they are so accurate it makes little difference.
 
 Today, at the cutting edge of physics there are lots of different theories being investigated to try and explain the structure of the universe on the scale of the very large and the incredibly small. Asking which one is true is meaningless, whichever proves to be the most accurate in time will be accepted until enough data can be accumulated to refine it further or, if necessary, discard it.
 
 Religion, however, has no proof, has no self-regulating system, is not based on repeatable observation and empirical evidence, and is very very old.

THere is the heisenberg uncertainty principle, which puts a bit of randomness into the equation.

 
 Unfortunately, nice idea as this is for suggesting the possibility of free will, it doesn't actually work.
 There are all sorts of weird quantum effects at the micro-microscopic level in addition to uncertainty, but in a physical system as complex as the brain is they get "washed out" by the sheer number of interactions going on at any one time.
 Even though some of these interactions involve literally a few particles, it is only when particles are isolated in the lab that we see weird quantum effects.
 
 I'm no physicist so I can't explain this as well as some others might, but the very fact that particles in the brain interact with each other all the time is a form of "measurement" which forces these particles out of an uncertain state and gets rid of any quantum randomness that might otherwise occur.
 
 So basically if we assume that the brain is a purely physical system and there is nothing beyond that, true free will is a no-no unfortunately.

 But hey, even then I'm sure JPSartre12 would find something "grossly" wrong with it! In other words, if JPSartre12 has it out for you, there's NOTHING you can say that s/he'll accept as being correct. S/he'll nitpick you to death over irrelevant matters: straining out a gnat and swallowing a camel, so to speak.
 
 
 
 2) Eagles have better eyesight than humans, but one would not likely therefore consider eagles to be at the top. When did an eagle ever program a computer, play a game of chess, blow up an enemy city? And we humans have the power to destroy eagles - and virtually all other life - not the other way around. 
 
 3) Bacteria have the potential to kill all humans, but that's about it (and, we have the power to kill them too). We sure can't say that they've mastered mathematics, or that they have sent themselves to the moon, and so on. Nor does their power extend past disease: they don't have thermonuclear weapons or bombs or missiles and so on - they don't have the power to destroy inanimate objects the way humans do.
 
 4) The sun puts out much more energy than humans can, but the sun can't write a poem, or read a book, or contemplate getting a college degree, and so on. And the sun is powerless to control its state: while humans can CONTROL where and when a thermonuclear reaction will occur, the sun can't do the same thing. The sun also can't change its own future: it's essentially just an enormous helpless, dumb thermonuclear powerplant 'adrift' in space.
 
 
 
 Nature is made up of living and nonliving things. 
 
 1) Inanimate: All known inanimate stuff is 'dumb': it all lacks thought processes and intelligence. We humans surely have the edge in intelligence over everything known that is inanimate. We also have the edge in many other ways, such as being able to change our future (i.e., we can MOVE ourselves somewhere else if we desire, unlike inanimate objects). And we have the power to destroy most inanimate things which we come into contact with, whereas only a few inanimate things have the power to destroy us (asteroids, for example).
 
 Oh, perhaps I should be more precise before JPSartre12 thinks he's found another imagined "fatal flaw" in my logic: before he takes a subatomic anthill and pretends it's Mt. Everest. The only inanimate things that are known to posses any degree of 'intelligence' are computers (and computerized robotics), but that is intelligence by proxy. WE HUMANS built them and infused them with their "intelligence". And, we can simply turn them off (at least for now!) any time we please, and they are reliant upon us for their functioning.
 
 
 2) Living: As far as known living things, we are at the top in terms of technology, intelligence, and power: the more key factors. We are the 'masters' of the living world (for 'power', there's the possible exception of bacteria, but then, as I already pointed out, they can't compare to our intelligence and technology).
 
 
 
 
Liminus: Sharks and crocodiles have been around for much longer than us, something like 300 million years, so these two species can certainly be seen as being more evolutionarily 'successful' than us, 

 
 Okay, but show me a shark or crocodile that can blow up the world. Show me a shark or crocodile that can create a computer. Show me a shark or crocodile that can play a game of chess. Show me a shark or crocodile that can gather a team together to figure how to rocket to the moon, and then achieve their goal. And so on. 
 
 Also, we humans were on the brink of completely wiping out some species of shark in certain areas: I've never heard of the opposite being true. 
 
 And going one step farther, if we wanted to, we could end both the shark's and the crocodile's long history here on the planet: they can't do the same to us.
 
 
Liminus: ... and we are no match for them in their own environment without a great deal of resources and effort being expended.

 
 I'll go up against a crocodile any day: just give me a rifle - you know, one of the many things the superior human intellect was able to build, that (even if it wasn't it's main intent) increasing our 'standing' in nature.
 
 
Liminus: So if I were to name any species as being at the 'top' of nature, it would have to be either sharks or crocodiles.

 
 And I'd have to strongly disagree with you. You gave only 1 reason to possibly believe that, and it doesn't seem like a good one at that.
 
 
Liminus: As another example, bacteria are extraordinarly successful; they have been around since practically the beginning of life, they multiply incredibly quickly and efficiently, they can survive in all kinds of environments, and for example if we had a nuclear apocalypse or a massive meteor impact, they can lie dormant for eons and begin replicating again when conditions are right. 

 
 There are problems with that. 
 
 First, you aren't talking about a type of organism, you are talking about an entire DOMAIN. That's comparing apples and oranges!
 
 For example, you aren't talking about a single species of bacteria that can live under all of those widely different conditions, but rather MANY DIFFERENT species of bacteria. You're trying to compare my single species - humans - to potentially millions of different species - bacteria: that's "cheating".
 
 Also, we have technology: they don't. We have intelligence: they don't. When's the last time a bacterium programmed a computer, or chatted on the internet, or investigated world history, or built a spaceship to send itself to another body in the solar system, or contemplated ways to destroy and asteroid heading for Earth, or decided to take charge of its life and change its behaviors, or debated another bacterium, or tried to reason to what it meant to live the good life, or ...?
 
 All in all, in the more key characteristics - intelligence, technology, and power - we humans come out on top.
 
 
 PS: I should also point out the CONTEXT of my statements. I was comparing the Christian/theistic view of humans with the atheist view. In the Christian view, there are several things above us: the main one is God. We humans are LOWLY according Christians, because there is a God we are compared to (there is not one good, no not one; all our works are as dirty rags; and so on ... oh, those are off the top of my head, so they are probably not exact quotes). In atheism, there is no God or gods. That alone elevates the standing of humans. That's actually good enough for me. Wheras Christianity says we humans are 'lowly' because it compares us to a suppose all-knowing, all-loving, all-powerful being; atheism doesn't hold this 'lowly' view of humans.

Wow. Do you get special lessons at school in how to be patronising?
 
 What I was getting at is that you said
 
 
the atheistic view, which is not based on God or divine revelation, is that humans are at the top of nature - we are the only thing known that could destroy the Earth, the only thing known to contemplate the past and future, and so on. And, atheists see death as final, and thus, bad.

 
 which I don't see as being the "atheistic view".
 
 Point taken about the 'top of nature' business, I just generally tend to react like that whenever anyone gets into the area of humans being superior to nature in general, because of our essentially fragile reliance on the ecosystem we live in. When you say
 
we are at the top in terms of technology, intelligence, and power, the more key factors

 
 Obviously that's unarguable, but my immediate reaction is to point out that we are not top in terms of "survivability" which is also slightly important.
 
 With that and the life after death bit, I was just taking issue with your generalising on atheists' philosophical beliefs.
